Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Rethinking HPC Resilience in the Exascale Era

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Resilience is one of the key exascale research challenges in high-performance<br/>computing (HPC). Due to much high error rates, exascale supercomputers could<br/>make little progress in computations, or might generate incorrect results due to<br/>failures, rendering the exascale performance useless. The<br/>challenge is how to achieve a complete HPC resilience at exascale in a way that<br/>does not increase the performance overhead, the power consumption, and the<br/>complexity of underlying hardware. To this end, this research project designs<br/>and develops low-cost hardware/software cooperative techniques for HPC<br/>resilience in the exascale era. <br/><br/>This project involves four research goals: (1) low-cost soft error resilience<br/>for CPUs; intelligent compiler-architecture interaction can validate the lack of<br/>errors and performs fine-grained recovery, thus eliminating SDC. (2)<br/>compiler-directed soft error resilience for commodity GPUs; it can remove the<br/>power-hungry error-correcting code (ECC) logic from the GPU register files<br/>without compromising their resilience. (3) lightweight nonvolatile memory (NVM)<br/>persistence; it can mitigate the overhead of traditional heavyweight HPC<br/>checkpointing and support whole-system persistence for applications without<br/>irrevocable operations. (4) low-cost timing error resilience for aggressive<br/>voltage scaling to maximize the energy-efficiency with program correctness<br/>guarantee.<br/><br/>The resulting artifacts and technologies are expected to contribute to the<br/>nation's competitiveness by addressing the challenge of building reliable HPC<br/>systems. The research outcome impacts a broad range of any disciplines that<br/>need correct computation results thus requiring reliable computing systems<br/>covering from embedded systems to HPC cloud. Consequently, use of the proposed<br/>techniques will make the execution of current and emerging applications much<br/>more reliable, and therefore directly affect our way of life.<br/><br/>There will be three types of data generated from this research project: (1)<br/>algorithms and models, (2) software prototype, (3) testing infrastructure<br/>including simulators and evaluation benchmarks and their traces, (4) educational<br/>materials. All of our software tools will be open source and made available to<br/>the public, laboratories and industry.
